TEXT: Good afternoon.
Thank you for standing by, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Coca-Cola Hellenic conference call on the third-quarter 2012 financial results.
At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode.
We will open with remarks by management, which will be followed by a question-and-answer session.
(Operator Instructions).
I would like to remind everyone that the purpose of the conference call is to talk with investors and therefore, questions from the media will not be addressed.
Media participants should call Coca-Cola Hellenic's international media contact if they have any questions.
I must advise you that this conference is being recorded today, Thursday, November 8, 2012.
We now pass the floor to one of your speakers, Ms. Oya Gur.
Please go ahead, ma'am.
Good afternoon, everyone and good morning to those of you in the United States.
Thank you for joining our call to discuss our third-quarter 2012 results.
Today, I am joined on the call by our Chief Executive Officer, Dimitris Lois and our Chief Financial Officer, Michalis Imellos.

These should be considered in conjunction with the cautionary statements contained in our related news release and the Company's most recent filings, copies of which can be found on our website at coca-colahellenic.com.
Let me now turn the call over to Dimitris.
Thank you, Oya and thank you to everyone for joining our call today.
In the third quarter, we achieved both volume and revenue growth in a very challenging macroeconomic and trading environment.
We continue to deliver on our strategic commitments as revenue grew ahead of volume in both the third quarter and the first nine months of the year.
Further, we gained or maintained volume share in sparkling beverages and value share in non-alcoholic ready-to-drink beverages in most of our countries.
Strong execution in the marketplace, as well as favorable base effects from the comparable prior-year period, contributed to a 2% volume growth in the quarter.
Volume in emerging markets grew by 7%, cycling a 7% decline in the same period last year.
In our developing markets, volume grew marginally while, in our established markets, volume declined by 3% in the quarter.
In terms of our overall financial performance, currency-neutral revenue per case, excluding the impact of Belarus, grew by 2% in the quarter.
A combination of higher volume and revenue resulted in marginally high operating profitability year-over-year.
Michalis will give you more details on our financials later.
Let's review our performance in light of our strategic commitments.

We are pleased to report that, in the third quarter, we grew or maintained our volume share in sparkling beverages category in most of our key markets, including Austria, Poland, Russia, Ukraine, Romania, the Czech Republic and Bulgaria.

We also gained or maintained value share in the overall non-alcoholic ready-to-drink beverage category in Switzerland, Austria, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Russia, Romania, Ukraine and Bulgaria, among others.
Economic and trading conditions remained tough across most of our markets and particularly the established ones.
Reduced disposable income and rising unemployment result in persistently low consumer confidence.
In addition, demand continues to shift towards larger retail formats and at-home consumption.
These continue to have an adverse impact on our package and channel mix.
Our OBPPC strategy focuses on addressing these challenges while driving revenue growth.
Let's now look at the specific performance of our key beverage categories and core brands in some more detail.
Volume of sparkling beverages grew by 3% in the third quarter.
Trademark Coca-Cola products were the key drivers growing by 3% year-on-year.
Brand Coca-Cola posted a 4% increase reflecting growth of 18% in Russia, 17% in Romania, 13% in Ukraine and 12% in Austria.
Volume of Coca-Cola Zero increased by 12% in the third quarter registering growth across all of our reporting segments.
Coca-Cola Zero grew by 33% in Italy, 17% in Hungary and 10% in Poland.
Volume in the juice category increased by 3% in emerging markets.
Total volume declined by 6% in the third quarter, mainly due to weaknesses in Greece, Ireland and Poland.
In Russia, volume in our juice category increased by 15% as we continued to increase our distribution reach and improve our execution capturing the benefits of the Multon Synergy Project.
Volume in the water category was slightly positive in developing and emerging markets.
The total volume declined by 1% in the third quarter mainly due to lower sales increase in Ukraine.
In line with our strategy, package mix improved during the quarter with single-serve packages outperforming across all of our reporting segments.
Turning to the performance of each of our reporting segments, volume in our established markets declined by 3% in the third quarter, cycling a 3% decline in the comparable prior-year period.
The economic challenges in the euro zone remain deep with no concrete signs of potential recovery.
Volume in Italy declined by low single digits in the quarter.
In the volatile environment characterized by a double-digit unemployment and low consumer confidence, we continue to focus on our strategic priorities.
In the quarter, volume of Coca-Cola Zero grew by 33% reflecting strong execution in specific channels, as well as sampling activities.
Package mix improved in the quarter with single-serve packages outperforming in both sparkling and water categories.
Volume increase declined by mid-teens in the third quarter as economic conditions continue to deteriorate.
In addition to a continuously contracting economy and rising unemployment, discussions over the finalization of a new EUR13.5 billion austerity package put more pressure on consumer sentiment.
The implementation of the new austerity measures will further reduce disposable income.
We continue to address affordability and mitigate the negative impact of net sales revenue per case through our OBPPC strategy.
Adapting our operating structure to an evolving marketplace and closely managing cash flow and working capital are top priorities in these circumstances.
Volume in Switzerland declined by mid-single digits during the quarter.
Our performance remains negatively affected by the strong Swiss franc versus the euro, which still will result in increased cross-border activity.
Package mix was stable in sparkling beverages and improved in the water category.
Activation in the modern trade supported a mid-single digit volume growth for Fanta while our key brands grew by low single digits.
We maintained both our volume and value NARTD share during the quarter.
Volume in Ireland continued the trend of previous quarters, declining by mid-single digits.
Fanta grew by low single digits and Coca-Cola Zero grew by low single digits even in this challenging environment.
At the same time, package mix improved driven by both the sparkling beverage and water categories.
The results were supported by a positive impact of our 350 millimeter PET bottle, which is one of our OBPPC initiatives in Ireland.
Volume in our developing market segment was marginally higher year-on-year, cycling a 2% decrease in the comparable prior-year period.
In Poland, volume increased by low single digits in the quarter.
Core sparkling beverages grew by high single digits reflecting growth across most core brands.
Specifically, Coca-Cola Zero, Fanta and Sprite posted double-digit growth in the quarter while Brand Coca-Cola grew by mid-single digits.
We gained both volume and value share in core sparkling beverages in the third quarter.
In Hungary, the external environment remains difficult.
The economy is still in recession and consumer confidence, as measured by the EU Commission, is one of the lowest in the European Union.
Coca-Cola Zero grew by high teens in the third quarter.
Volume of our key brands grew by low single digits due to the strong performance of Nestea Green Tea with Stevia.
We increased our value share in both the sparkling and NARTD categories during the quarter.
This was the last quarter that our comparables were impacted by the public sales tax introduced in September 2011.
Volume in the Czech Republic increased by low single digits in the third quarter.
Strong promotional activity, particularly in the modern trade and overall better weather supported volume.
Sparkling beverages grew by low single digits driven by a mid-single digit increase in Coca-Cola and Coca-Cola Zero, a high single digit increase in Sprite and a high teens increase in Fanta.
During the quarter, we have gained share in both sparkling beverages and total NARTD.
We expect volatile conditions to persist in the Czech Republic.
Volume in our emerging markets segment posted a 7% volume increase in the third quarter, cycling a 7% decline in the comparable prior-year period.
Russia grew by just under 10% with volume growing across most key categories.
We continue to win in the marketplace in our largest market.
In the third quarter, we gained share in the sparkling beverages category.
Brand Coca-Cola grew by 18%, coupled with a 15% growth in Fanta and a 7% growth in Sprite.
Our volume in the juice category grew by 15% on the back of a double-digit growth in both our [core brand], Dobry and our premium juice brand, Rich.
We continue to invest in our brands together with our partners in growth, The Coca-Cola Company, in order to remain best placed to capture the significant growth potential that Russia offers.
Volume in Nigeria increased by mid-single digits in the quarter, cycling a mid-single digit decline during the same period last year.
Our strategy in Nigeria remains focused on expanding distribution and volume per outlet.
Volume of trademark Coca-Cola products increased by mid-single digits in the quarter and Sprite grew by low single digits year-over-year.
Increased availability and strong activation supported double-digit growth in our juice and water categories.
In water, we launched a lightweight PET bottle in the third quarter.
Volume in Ukraine declined by mid-single digits in the third quarter driven by lower sales in the water category.
The overall environment remains challenging in Ukraine and currency volatility is expected to continue.
The total non-alcoholic ready-to-drink beverages market has declined by 17% year-to-date.
Strong activation in the modern trade resulted in mid-teens growth for Brand Coca-Cola, high single digit growth for Sprite and mid-single digit growth for Fanta.
We continue to outperform competition gaining volume and value share in both sparkling beverages and the total non-alcoholic ready-to-drink.
Looking ahead, we expect volatile conditions to persist across most of our territories.
Particularly in our established markets, disposable income will be under further pressure in the months to come as new austerity measures are being implemented.
We expect that consumer confidence will continue to suffer as the eurozone debt crisis, so no signs of resolution.
We remain focused on delivering in line with our strategic priorities -- continue winning in the marketplace and keep growing both revenue and volume with revenue faster than volume.

Our OBPPC initiatives enable us to tailor our approach to the unique characteristics of each of our markets, enabling us to execute our revenue growth management strategy while staying relevant to the consumers.
Our focus on pursuing cost leadership is unwavering.

We continue the execution of our accelerated restructuring initiatives, which touch all aspects of our busines -- infrastructure optimization, process efficiency, operating expense control and systems exploitation as reflected by our SAP Wave 2 and Shared Services Center Implementation.
Sustained and strong cash flow generation through tight working capital management and ultimately better operating profitability remains a top priority.

Before I hand over to Michalis, let me reiterate the recently announced voluntary share exchange offer by Coca-Cola HBC AG, which will facilitate the listing of the group in the premium segment of the London Stock Exchange.
We are currently working with the regulators in the UK, the US and Greece on our offer documents.
We are making good progress and expect that the voluntary exchange offer will be completed early in the first quarter of 2013.

The tender offer period will commence once all the offer documents are approved by the relevant regulatory authorities and we will be issuing separate communication on that prior to the start of the tender offer.
Upon reaching control of at least 90% of the voting shares, we will initiate a squeeze-out procedure for any remaining shares that have not been tendered in accordance with Greek law.
We intend to seek inclusion in the FTSE 100 Index after completion of the squeeze-out.
And with that, let me now hand over to Michalis.
Thank you, Dimitris and hello, everyone.

In line with our practice, as I take you through our financial results for the third quarter, I will refer to comparable figures, excluding, first, the impact of restructuring costs incurred in all periods under review; second, the mark-to-market valuation impact of commodity hedges; and third, non-recurring items pertaining to costs related to the recently announced transaction.

In addition, where applicable, I will refer to figures excluding the hyperinflation impact of Belarus in order to illustrate the actual underlying trends as the impact of the hyperinflationary conditions in Belarus can be material year-over-year.
As Dimitris discussed earlier, we were able to grow both revenue and volume in the third quarter despite an increasingly volatile environment, particularly in our established markets.
We continue to deliver on our strategic commitments with total revenue growing by 6% year-over-year, faster than the 2% volume growth in the same period.
As a result, for the first nine months of the year, total revenue is growing by 3%, while volume is declining by 1%.
Currency-neutral revenue per case, excluding the impact of Belarus, grew by 2% in the third quarter and by 3% in the first nine months.
During the quarter, growth in currency-neutral revenue per case was driven by a 6% increase in emerging and a 2% increase in developing markets.
As experienced in previous quarters, the continuing pressures on disposable income and consumer confidence contributed to a 1% decline in currency-neutral revenue per case in established markets.
Currency-neutral input costs per case, excluding the impact of Belarus, grew by 4.5% in the third quarter and by 6% in the first nine months of the year.
EU sugar prices remained a key driver of higher input costs.

Consequently, our developing and established markets were affected the most in the quarter with currency-neutral input costs growing in the mid-single digits in established and mid-teens in developing.
On the other hand, currency-neutral input costs per case, excluding the impact of Belarus, saw a marginal year-over-year increase in emerging markets.
Our financial performance continued to be negatively affected by currency movements in the quarter.
In the third quarter, we incurred an approximately EUR15 million negative impact on operating profit with the impact for the first nine months being EUR48 million.
The majority of the adverse impact in both periods comes from transactional currency exposures on input costs.
As a reminder, for a transactional currency impact perspective, we have substantially hedged our exposure since late quarter two in line with our hedging policy.
Currency-neutral operating expenses per case, excluding the impact of Belarus, declined by 2% in the quarter and were 1% higher year-over-year in the first nine months.
This reflects the year-over-year phasing of our marketing spend with a relevant catchup expected in quarter four this year.
Improving operating efficiency and driving productivity remains a key focus area.
During the third quarter, six more countries joined our Shared Service Center in Bulgaria where certain processes of our finance and human resources functions are centralized.
Another three countries joined recently, bringing the total number of countries currently serviced by our Shared Service Center to 19.
More countries are scheduled to go live in the next six months and more processes will transition after that.
Our comparable EBIT in the third quarter closed at EUR221 million, registering a marginal 0.5% improvement year-over-year.
The positive impact of our revenue growth initiatives and volume growth offset the pressures from higher input costs and unfavorable currency movements.
In the first nine months of the year, comparable EBIT declined by EUR56 million.
Turning now to the individual reporting segments' performance.
In our established markets, comparable operating profit declined by 26% year-over-year in the third quarter.
Lower volume and higher input costs were the main drivers of this decline.
The economic environment remains extremely challenging across most of the segment with no signs of recovery yet.

In our developing markets, higher input costs and unfavorable currency movements more than offset the benefits of our revenue growth initiatives resulting in a 21% decline in comparable operating profit in the third quarter.
In line with expectations, our emerging markets drove the group's profit in the third quarter with comparable operating profit increasing by 37% year-over-year.

The positive impact of our revenue growth initiatives, volume growth and improved category mix more than offset the negative impact of increased input costs and favorable transaction currency impact and higher operating expenses year-over-year.

Below the operating line, net financing costs stood at EUR24.4 million, growing by EUR3.6 million year-over-year, mainly due to lower interest income and lower net FX gains on balance sheet items in remeasurement.
Actual interest expenses were broadly flat in the quarter and we expect this to be the case for the full year as well.
We generated free cash flow of EUR285 million in the third quarter of 2012 and EUR381 million for the nine months.
At the same time, our working capital continues to improve with cash generated from working capital reduction reaching approximately EUR135 million in the third quarter.
Strong and sustained cash flow generation is a key focus area and we maintain our guidance for free cash flow of EUR1.45 billion for the three-year period ending December 2014.

Looking ahead, our three-year business planning cycle is currently in progress, so we will be in position to give you a more detailed view on our outlook at the time of our full-year results announcement in February.
Having said that, let me give you some color on how we see things evolving over the next few months.
Economic and trading conditions remain challenging across most of our territories.
As Dimitris mentioned, we remain focused on delivering on our strategic priorities.

We, therefore, continue to expect for the balance of the year that currency-neutral revenue per case will continue to grow, albeit at a slower pace and that the benefits of our revenue growth initiatives will cover the total input cost increase in absolute terms.
The overall input cost environment has evolved in line with our expectations and we anticipate a mid-single digit increase in currency-neutral input costs per case for the full year.
In terms of currencies, there have been some favorable trends in recent months with some of our key developing and emerging markets' currencies appreciating versus the euro.
Having said that, the overall environment remains volatile.

Based on current spot rates and taking into account the timing of the hedging positions taken against our various currencies, we anticipate a slight improvement over the previous currency [HEAP] guidance of EUR55 million for the full year.
We proceed with the implementation of the recently announced accelerated restructuring plans.
We continue to expect pretax restructuring charges of around EUR100 million in 2012.
Approximately half of these are non-cash related to provisions, which will be booked in the fourth quarter of the year.
The expected annualized benefits accruing in 2013 and beyond are estimated at EUR70 million.
The total benefits this year from the initiatives undertaken or to be undertaken in both 2011 and 2012 are expected to reach approximately EUR50 million.
Before we open the floor for questions, I would like to give you an update on the financing aspects of the voluntary share exchange offer.
As previously announced, we had secured a total of EUR1.55 billion financing facility for the purpose of the transaction.
EUR500 million of the financing was arranged in the event of a need to replace our existing revolver credit facility.
We have now secured transfer of this facility to Coca-Cola HBC AG, which will take place at the appropriate time following the successful completion of the exchange offer.
Therefore, EUR0.5 billion of the EUR1.55 billion facility is no longer required and has been canceled with no costs incurred.
We, therefore, now have available a EUR1.05 billion bridge facility.
Out of this, a portion up to a maximum of EUR550 million will be used for the mandatory buyout of the minorities during the squeeze-out period.
Any unused amount will be canceled.
The last EUR500 million portion will also be canceled when we have accessed the debt markets at some point next year to refinance our bond maturities.
And with that, Dimitris and I are ready to respond to your questions.
(Operator Instructions).
Lauren Torres, HSBC.
Hi, everyone.
My question is on established market performance in the quarter.
I think this was the first quarter this year where your revenue decline was greater than your volume decline.

And as you've always spoken about growing revenue ahead of volume, I was just curious if this is a trend that we think can continue or should continue, particularly as we talk about the environment getting tougher looking into next year.
What type of initiatives do you have or do you think you can help revenue grow ahead of volume in this particular group of countries?
Yes, Lauren, what we have seen is a clear reflection of the challenges in our established markets.
And as this sort of proceeds, and as we have been sharing prior with our comments, this is something that we see continue.
We don't see any clear evidence of stabilization.
Our strategy is very clear.
We want in all of our segments to grow our revenue ahead of the volume.
That is why we are focusing behind our OBPPC and our single-serve and this is something that will continue for the next couple of quarters.
Now, with that in mind, I want to give a little bit of a light with regards to what we see as far as trends are concerned, which confirm that the established are really challenged.
The macroeconomic environment across most of the countries remains unchanged.
We don't see any evidence of stabilization.
That is why we expect that Q4 also is going to be quite challenging.
I'm not sure if you want to comment though on next year.
I am just curious if this trend will continue where your revenue declines will be greater than your volume declines?
You are talking about next year now?
Right.
Let me clarify one thing.
First of all, the volume for Q3 was minus 3%.
The NSR per case was minus 1%.
So with that in mind, we see that the revenue is doing better than the volume.
I just wanted to clarify that.
Minus 3% volume and the revenue per case is minus 1%.
So your comment applies and your comment is correct.
Now with regards to next year, right now, the only thing that I want to reiterate is the fact that the conditions are extremely challenging.
Now with that in mind, I don't want you to translate that as this is something that we expect will continue.
What I want to reiterate is extremely challenging conditions.
We are relentless behind the revenue growing faster than the volume and we will persist on this strategy.
And Lauren, just to quickly build on Dimitris' comment, the minus 1% revenue per case year-over-year growth is what we have seen in the last three quarters.
So at least there, there has been some consistency due to the challenging conditions that Dimitris mentioned in the established markets.
Understood.
Jon Fell, Deutsche Bank.
Hello, everybody.
I want to ask a question about the free cash flow guidance for the next three years.
You have reiterated again today you expect to produce EUR1.45 billion.
As I look at consensus and indeed my own forecasts, we appear to be something in the range of EUR250 million below that.
We know what CapEx is going to be, we know roughly what the tax rate is going to be, so I am thinking that in order for your guidance to be correct, then the markets' profit numbers have to be wrong.
And where are we going to be wrong?
Are you expecting a recovery in volumes at some point or have we got the [in person], the cost dynamic wrong?

Is there a scope for a big upside there or given where your margins and returns have dropped to, are you going to have to have a tough conversation with The Coca-Cola Company at some point and say, look, you are taking too much out of these markets?
I don't know whether I would go as far as that, but, obviously, we haven't seen your models in detail.
What I would say is that clearly we said in the past that this is backloaded in terms of the cash generation.
In the earlier part of the three years, we focus more on working capital reduction and the cash, incremental cash that is coming from there.
You are right about the tax in terms of the guidance of 24%, 25% to 27% effective tax rate, but also there might be some other small cash flows that can come from other activities.
It is not just the operating cash, the working capital and the tax.
So we are going to come with a reiteration of our guidance in the next quarter when our planning cycle has been completed.
Right now, based on all available information that we have, we reiterate the guidance of EUR1.45 billion.
So when you talk about some other cash flow items, I mean is there a prospect of reasonable size disposals, which then could be boosting reported cash flows?

Well, I don't think that right now we are in a position to commit to something specific, but all I was trying to highlight is that it is not just those two or three items that you mentioned that contribute to the cash flow.
Okay, thanks very much.
Stam Draziotis, Eurobank.
Yes, hi there, yes.
I know you said that you are going to give a more detailed outlook at the Q4 results, but I was just wondering, you have mentioned that the expectation for FX neutral.
Input cost inflation remains at mid-single digits for 2012.
I was wondering what would you see at the moment looking forward into next year, if you could give us some insight on raw material inflation for next year at this stage.
And secondly, I saw there was some sort of normalization of trading in Italy in Q3, so volumes were down low single digits from I think it was near 10% in Q2.
Could you maybe elaborate a bit on the business there and if you could comment on maybe the outlook for the coming quarters.
I will take the first question and then Dimitris will take the second.
In terms of the input costs next year, obviously, as you said, we are in the relatively early stage to have the best view.
What we can say at this point in time is that we still see growth to currency-neutral input costs per case in 2013.
Albeit it will be at a slower pace than what we saw in 2012.
This is as far as we can go at this point in time.
We will come with something more specific in February.
Okay, fair enough.
With regards to Italy, I wouldn't call it normalization and I am saying that you are absolutely right.
The decline in Q3 was a low single digit and when you compare that with Q2, there is a difference.
But I wouldn't call it normalization because you might recall that, in Q2, also we had very adverse weather conditions that affected.

So what we need to remember is that the macro conditions are deteriorating and employment has reached a double-digit for the first time in the last decade and consumer confidence has been declining by I think almost 14 index points year-on-year in the quarter.
So very tough trading conditions and those are expected to continue.
So this in principle is part of what we see in all of our established markets.
So that is why I wanted just to clarify this is not really a normalization.
We have to take into consideration the different effects in the market within Q2 and Q3.
Okay, thanks very much.
Andrew Holland, Societe Generale.
A couple questions.
Could you -- you mentioned a couple of times I think specifically to countries, what was going on with single-serve packages or immediate consumption.
Could you sort of give us an idea across the whole business of what is happening with immediate consumption?
And perhaps related to that, what is happening to your cooler investment, which I recall was quite a big deal a few years ago and we haven't heard much about it recently?
And then a second question is you refer to flat interest charge for the full year or financing cost.
Is that a flat interest charge or an overall flat financing cost?
I just noticed there is a modest difference in what that was last year.
Okay, Andrew, let me take the first bit of your question and then Michalis will help us.
Now, overall across all of our markets and again, far more evident in the established, we see that immediate consumption suffers and it has been suffering for quite some time.
So that is one element.

Obviously, this affects, to a certain degree, our single-serve packages and I am saying to a certain degree because taking into consideration our key strategic initiative, which is OBPPC, there is an element behind our single-serve and our single-serve multipacks.
So in principle, the strategy is behind expanding single-serve through the multipacks format and eventually take the single-serve at-home consumption.
This is a process that it will take time.
But this is something that we are following and we are very focused behind this strategic initiative.
So overall, immediate consumption suffers far more evident in the established markets.
This drives the single-serve down.
We have a mitigation strategy and we have started using this mitigation strategy, which is one of the key pillars behind our OBPPC.

With regards to your coolers investment, what we have been sharing is when we are evaluating our CapEx, our first priority is behind revenue-generating initiatives and a key element behind revenue-generating initiatives are coolers.
So we have been and we will be investing quite a bit behind coolers because eventually this also supports our single-serve focus.
So yes, we will be investing behind coolers.
Now let me sort of give the floor to Michalis to take your second question.
So let me clarify, first of all, we refer to the net financing costs and these comprise four elements, they are on the back of the press release if you want to refer to them.
I'm sure you have seen it because you picked up the growth.

The main -- as you can see, the main areas where the growth is coming from is not from the gross financing interest costs; it is coming from some balanced item remeasurement lines and also the interest income as a result of the lower year-over-year interest rates.
The actual financing cost, the actual interest cost is more or less flat year-over-year.
Year to date nine, we are EUR500,000 more than prior year on a EUR73 million expense.
So this is where we see that's exactly the element that we see continuing flat year-over-year.
Right, okay.
So on top of that, there could be FX gains and losses on net monetary positions that mean that the overall figure is different from and possibly lower than last year?
Well, right now, on a year-to-date nine basis, we are EUR4.4 million higher.
As I said, the interest expense is flattish, EUR0.5 million more.
We have the foreign exchange losses more or less at zero.
This is on the balance sheet items remeasurement.
The interest income right now is flat, but in quarter three, it was EUR1 million down as we experienced less and less interest income due to the rate.
And the loss on the net monetary position is actually the Belarus hyperinflation impact.
So assuming that inflation rates in Belarus normalize, then this will not create again next year a big year-over-year effect.
That's helpful.
Henry Davies, Bank of America.
Hi, guys, yes, I have got three questions, please.
First, how much did [A&P] decline in the first nine months or maybe you can tell us what OpEx was up if you ex out the decline in A&P.
Second, on input costs, could you perhaps break down your guidance for slight inflation by input?
And also if FX remains where it is today, what would the transactional FX benefit be next year?
And then thirdly, just to clarify on free cash flow, if you did make a disposal, would that be included in your free cash flow to compare to your guidance?
And on a longer-term view, where do you see -- where do you think you can improve your working capital to?
Okay, so let me start with the input costs for this year.
This year, we have seen primarily the EU sugar being the main driver of growth.
This is -- and that is why you will see established and developing markets having the biggest input cost hit year-over-year.
PET resin started in the year with a relatively high growth, but it eased during the middle of the year and we see this trend continuing, still growing, but easing from the beginning of the year.
Aluminum has grown, has been growing, so these are the three, if you like, major elements that have been growing.
What has been easing year-over-year has been world sugar and this is where there has been some help in the emerging markets' input cost.
It is not growing as fast as the other two segments.
In terms of transactional effects, we are not, at this point in time, in a position to give guidance for next year.
We continue to see an FX shift for next year.
We are not right now in a position to give a more specific figure.
Our hedging policy allows for hedging in three to six months ahead on a rolling basis.
So right now, we are hedged pretty well for quarter one and to a lesser extent for quarter two.

On the free cash flow and the working capital reduction, so it was earlier a general comment once again that we don't focus on just one or two areas; we drive incremental cash across the different elements.
Working capital, we have a mid-term target to go down to zero by the end of 2015, zero balance of working capital.
Now your first question was around the DME, the advertising costs.
We had, during the quarter three, a year-over-year decrease.
This is to do purely with the phasing of how the marketing spend is booked between quarters this year and last year.
If you exclude this decline in the marketing spend, the rest of the OpEx overall per case currency-neutral grew by very low single digits.
Perfect.
Just a couple of follow-ups.

My question on input costs was more on the 2013 outlook and then just on the FX, my understanding was that given the euro has been strengthening against the dollar again that maybe that transactional FX impact should turn positive next year.
And then just on A&P, can you tell us what it did for the nine months?
Also was it flattish in the nine months and this is just a quarterly thing or was it also down in the nine months?
For 2013, as we were discussing earlier, it is too early to take a firm position.
What we see at this point in time is still growth on the currency-neutral input costs per case in 2013, but at a slower pace than the 2012 growth.
In terms of overall the marketing expenses per case year-to-date nine, it is a very small decline so far, but we expect a catchup in quarter four, as I mentioned earlier.
And sorry, did you say you had another follow-up?
Yes, it was the transactional FX.
I thought that given the euro has strengthened again that that may turn positive into next year.
Just maybe some color on why that will still be negative.
Yes, as I mentioned earlier, our hedging policy calls for a three to six-month rolling hedging.
So obviously it depends very much on the timing of when the payer performs and it is not just the euro/dollar; it is also the ruble to the dollar.

It is the Polish zloty to the dollar, naira to the dollar and the Romanian lei to the dollar because all of these are major exposures in terms of resin and sugar purchases, which drive the transactional effects hit.
Okay, perfect.
So if those five currencies stay where they are today, it would be a negative next year basically?

Well, if they improve versus what has happened this year, it is a very difficult calculation to make because you have to take into account exactly what hedging positions were taken throughout this year in order to estimate what exactly is the impact for next year.
Okay, perfect.
Adam Spielman, Citi.
Hello, thank you very much for taking the question.
If I can turn to two of your most important growth markets, firstly Russia and then Nigeria, in Russia, you say that obviously volume grew this year, but you mentioned that there was an easy comp.
Now I just want to examine that because my understanding is the reason your volumes were down in Q3 '11 is really because the Q '10 figure was so inflated.

What I am getting at or what I really want to understand is was the performance in Russia that you reported good because you had a weak Q3 '11 or is it just that it is intrinsically good because actually Q3 '11 wasn't weak and that is what seems to me the case.
That is the first question.

And secondly, some other beverage companies in Nigeria are saying the underlying operating environment is actually improving and improved during the quarter, quarter three and I was just wondering if you could give -- if you have seen that and if you think the business there is getting stronger, consumer confidence getting stronger?
On Russia, we are optimistic and I am saying that because I understand your point with regards to the cycling.
The business is doing well.
The consumer environment is good, all cylinders are firing and I am saying that because we have been consistently growing across.
That covers sparkling, that covers tea, energy and we are doing also very well in juice.
So we are very optimistic with our strategy and we are very optimistic with regards to the overall external environment.
So good point for clarification.
Now moving to Nigeria, what we have seen this quarter was a positive evolution mid-single digit.
Now I don't want to comment overall with regards to consumer and consumer confidence because it is I think premature to comment with regards to consumer confidence looking at one quarter.
And I am saying that because what we have seen from the beginning of the year is two things.
The first thing is the overall turbulence in the northern part and we are very strong in the northern part.
Obviously, that is affecting our volume evolution.
And the second thing, in the beginning of the year, the subsidy in fuel was taken away.
The fuel price went from NGN65 to NGN100.

So obviously, this drives disposable income, which is short to medium term and additionally, it drove a very important decline in the volume of Q1, which is one of the strongest quarters along with Q4.
So all in all, yes, we are happy to see the single-digit growth in the quarter and that is across sparkling juice and water.
And specifically for juice and water, we have seen a double-digit growth and we need to allow a few more quarters and then evaluate the consumer and the consumer confidence in Nigeria.
Iakovos Kourtesis, National Securities.
Good afternoon, gentlemen.
What I would like to ask is, first of all, you have said something about the structure and guidance, non-cash items, in the last quarter of around EUR50 million.
If you could give us some color there.
The second question is about working capital conditions in Greece.
I suppose Greece is a much more difficult market, this market for Greece, compared to other markets you operate.
I was wondering if you noticed that the working capital (inaudible) in Greece mainly refer to the small grocery shops or also large chains.
And in terms of your volume (inaudible), I was wondering -- you said that you expect this to be completed early in 2013.
Do you expect to commence trading (inaudible) before or after the announcement of first-quarter results?
That will be.
First of all, on the restructuring, we have incurred so far around 25% of the full-year cost that we have flagged, the EUR100 million.

What we were saying about the non-cash is that, out of the EUR75 million in quarter four, more or less, half of this is going to be non-cash-related because it relates to certain provisions that will be made following specific announcements in line with the accounting policy.
So that was the comment around the half being non-cash items and therefore not having an impact on the free cash flow of the year.
In terms of the working capital conditions in Greece, and I guess you refer to (inaudible) primarily.
I think the performance there in an extremely difficult and challenging environment, which is characterized by lack of liquidity in the market, is very, very good.
We are keeping our position in terms of receivables days.
There is only a very, very slight deterioration, which, in the circumstances, I believe it's very satisfactory and the general issue is definitely liquidity.
We manage working capital in Greece very tightly, watching very closely our credit policy and the credit limits with our customers trying to keep open positions as minimized as possible.
In terms of -- your third question was around the listing on the London Stock Exchange.
The listing will take place immediately after the end of the acceptance period.
Right now, we see this based on the evolution of the different stages being very early quarter one.
I think it is difficult right now to pinpoint whether it will be before or after our quarter-four results announcement.
It will be very, very close.
And one last thing, if I may ask, how many countries are live on your SAP platform now and is Russia included in them?
By January, so in a couple of months, we will have all the countries of Hellenic on the platform except for Nigeria.
Thank you very much.
Operator, let's have one more question and then hand the call over to Dimitris for his closing remarks.
Olivier Nicolai, UBS.
Hi, good afternoon.
Actually I have got three questions.
Just last month, you told us that 61% of your shareholders were committed to proceed to the Exchange.
Could you just give us an update on this percentage?
My second question is related to the minus 26% of EBIT in Q3 in established markets.
Could you just talk us through the dynamics there?
How much of this decline was due to the negative mix or how much of this was due to the input cost inflation?
And the last question I have is on the Czech Republic.
Do you see any increased competition from the beer category and I am particularly thinking about the Radler beer category versus soft drinks?
On your first question, the 61% refers to the irrevocable commitments that we have before launching the transaction.
Obviously, these do not change and we are not -- the acceptance period has not started yet.
So this percentage will not go up or down before obviously the end of the acceptance period where we will know how much above the 90% we will be.
Your second question on established markets' profitability in quarter three, the main drivers for the decline were volume, lower volume and higher input costs.

Dimitris has mentioned that the macroeconomic conditions have been extremely challenging in this segment, reduced disposable income, rising unemployment, low consumer confidence and also the shift of the channel towards the modern trade and also towards at-home consumption also put pressure on the margins.
Revenue per case, as we also discussed earlier, currency-neutral declined by 1%.
This is what we have seen consistently in the last three quarters.

Currency-neutral input costs per case increased by 6% and the primary driver here is EU sugar prices, higher sugar prices year-over-year and finally, currency-neutral operating expenses declined by 4% and this is the result of consistent restructuring activities and investments in restructuring activities that have taken place across the segment.
On your last question with regards to Radlers, well, overall and depending on the market, we consider beer as being a competitive product.
Now, what we have seen -- it is in part of our territory, mostly I would say in the western Balkans and this is something that we have seen probably more than a year and a half now.
So we are winning marketshare overall.
We haven't seen a big outflow of consumers from our space to the Radlers, but it is too early to comment more than that.
It is something which is new.
I would say more localized in a few countries within the western Balkans and in any case, the overall beer category is a category that we consider as being competitive to us.
Okay, very good.
Thank you very much.
I want to thank you for joining us today and for all the excellent questions that promoted a good discussion around our third-quarter performance.
We achieved volume and revenue growth and a marginal improvement in EBIT in an increasingly volatile environment.

We believe that we have the right strategy to successfully respond to the challenges in the marketplace and capitalize on the significant growth potential of our country portfolio when external conditions begin to stabilize.
We look forward to updating you in February on our full-year performance as a company listed in the premium segment of the London Stock Exchange.
And with that, I want to thank you all for being with us today.
And with many thanks to all our speakers today, that does conclude the conference.
You may now all disconnect.
